ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I was able to build up a knowledge of the history of the notion of 'Japaneseness', its relations to the emperor system, and the great perturbations that affected the identity over the course of the 19th and 20th centuries. Moreover, I was able to learn about the various ideologies and justifications undergirding the Japanese government's sidelining of indigenous and minority groups, while gaining valuable insight into the history of other minoritised groups in Japan along the lines of gender, sexuality, and disability. I was also able to sharpen my skills in film analysis through more precise terminology and robust feedback from Professor Gerow as well as through the wide array of films that were screened during class.
I gained a lot in terms of learning the "otherness" of Japanese society. Learning through film was a very engaging first-hand method to study these perceptions of "others" in a more personal level.
I learned about how to analyze "others" in Japanese cinema.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Immersive, wide array of material, passionate and knowledgeable instructor
Weaknesses: Workload could feel heavy at times, particularly for some weeks with five sessions (normal lessons, screenings, graduate sessions, and Zoom meetings with filmmakers)
Great choices of films, engaging way of teaching by Dr. Gerow, fantastic zoom sessions with the directors.

Strength: Prof.Gerow organizes film screenings every week. It's a good chance for us to know different film genres.
Weakness: This course involves too many political perspective analyses, which reduces its "filmness" to some extent.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes  Professor Gerow was engaging, warm, and infectious with his depth of knowledge and passion. I enjoyed the vast array of films he introduced to the class and his lectures, assigned reading, and films that he screened were rich and complex. However, the course may prove challenging for those without much background knowledge in Japanese or East Asian Studies.
Yes. This course offers a great opportunity to study the minorities in Japan, as well as Japanese films.
